para.text: SYNOPSIS

This is based on the remarkable true life story of Annie Besant (847-1934) A strong orator, energetic activist and idealist, this Englishwoman mixed with the leading politicians and writers of her day. A modern women, a pioneer of the feminist movement yet a deeply spiritual person.

The script covers her journey from a deeply religious and sheltered life to gaining awareness of the poverty and misery of the the poor. By chance, she stumbles into the then popular of spiritualism, secularism and socialism and becomes a well-known activist in the trade union movement and for women's rights. In London, she was a friend of Oscar Wilde and other society people as well as the lover of George Bernard Shaw. But she never quite threw off her spiritual side and, at the height of her popularity, suddenly turned her back on political life and joined Madame Blavatsky, the notorious Russian who founded the Theosophical Society. Annie Besant eventually became President the Society and moved to India. She adopted Krishnamurti, who went on to become a world-renown teacher and philosopher. Annie returned eventually to politics and became the only white women to head the Indian National Congress where she fought alongside Gandhi for home rule.

This is the story of a woman who succeeded against the odds by her power with words and became a beacon for women who followed. Yet she was also a flawed character, lacking humour and misled by men. Right up to her old age she was still searching for a truth that always seem to eluded her but finds some reconciliation in her last years.

Our amazing tale takes us from England to America, India, Sri Lanka and Singapore as Annie pursues her passions. The story offers many opportunities in capturing life and scenes from the Victorian era, in London and the more exotic places. Apart from the roles offered to the three or four actors portraying Annie, there are many cameo performances which will excite actors.
I would hope that funding from England, India and Singapore as well as the USA would assist the financing of production.
THE MANY LIVES OF ANNIE BESANT
EXT prison yard
It is 1867 in Birmingham, England. A group of prisoners are being loaded onto a windowless wagon drawn by horses.
Prison Guard
OK, you can bring out the two special prisoners now.

The two leaders of the Irish Republican Brotherhood and led out. They stand proud and defiant and are also led into the wagon. A policeman gets inside with the prisoners. Two policemen sit in front behind the horses. The gates open and the wagon leaves the prison yard.
EXT: STREET SCENE

As the carriage rattles down the road, it enters a tunnel. A man halts the horse drawn wagon with a pistol. As it stops a mob of thirty or more men climb over a wall and surround the wagon, shooting in the air and shooting a horse. The policemen on the front are pulled off and beaten. A frightened horse is shot. The attackers try to open the door but it is locked. One tries to shoot out the lock.
INT. Prison Wagon
Unfortunately the policeman inside decides at that time to look through the key hole and is shot through the eye and is killed.
Police SergeanT:
Ahh,Ahh
Prisoner 1 (from inside)
Yer gone and shot the frikking policeman, yer silly bastards.
PrIsoner 2
Bloody mad Irishmen! Hey,look. I can get the keys off this poor bastard.
The prisoner removes the keys from the dead policeman and undoes the long chain holding them together and then passes the keys out through a ventilation grill to one of the mob .
Ext:street
The gang unlock the door and the prisoners inside start to jump out.
RESCUER(Irish accent):
Which one of you are Thomas Kelly and Timothy Deasy? Come on , take these horses and ride like the wind.
The two men come out from the back of the wagon and are helped onto waiting horses. The gang disperse leaving the empty wagon, a dying horse, and two badly beaten policemen and a dead one.
EXT: Same location an hour later
The police are cleaning up. The dead policeman's body is being removed. The police commissioner is there with a Sergeant and other men. A police constable runs up.
police constable:
Sir, we have recaptured four of the prisoners hiding in the park.
They tell us it was a gang of Irishman who wanted to rescue

the two leaders of what they call the Irish Republican Brotherhood.I'm afraid those two got clean away on horseback. The other prisoners say they were not part of this and didn't know about the attack.
Police commissioner

Well done, lad. Go and try to round up the rest.(he turns to his Sergeant). I guessed it was those micks. Well, they will be sorry if they think they can kill one of our men and escape. I want you to round up everyone with a connection to this Irish Home Rule nonsense. Nay, every bloody man with an Irish accent in this city is a suspect. We can find witnesses to identify them, don't worry.
BELOW IS SUGGESTED SCENE FOR OPENING TITLES OF MOVIE. The scene and music in contrast to the violent action shown previously.
EXT: Large English Protestant Church. The camera moves slowly towards the church
INT: Inside the Church

The camera moves slowly towards the front. Inside the immense church we become aware of a diminutive figure. A girl of 7 or 8 years old is on her knees praying. She is alone. We see she is looking up with adoration at the figure of Jesus Christ.
Annie:

Oh Lord, please hear my prayers. I know my poppa is by your side now in Heaven. Please let him know I miss him ever so much. Also please keep Mama safe and stop my brother Henry sinning all the time. Help us, dear Jesus, to grow better each day and deliver us from evil. I am sorry you had to suffer to free us from from mortal sin. Dear Jesus, I hope you you love me as much as I love you. When I am bigger, I promise to do your work here on Earth. I will fight the Christian fight and slay all your enemies. May God forgive those who have sinned against you (her voice is echoed by a male voice)
INT:courtroom
The image of Christ's face on the statue fades into that of a young man, looking stunned
The camera pulls back to show three men in the dock of a courtroom. We see a judge passing sentence on three young men in the dock. One is just 19.
JUDGE:

May God forgive your sins. I hereby sentence you, William Allen, Michael Larkin and Michael O'Brien to hang by the neck until dead. While you wait, for this sentence to be carried out, think of the widow and child of that poor policeman you brutally killed. Take them away.
We see Annie, now a young girl of sixteen, crying in the public gallery. She is comforted by a distinguished looking man. As the men are led out they shout
Manchester Martyrs: (shouting)
Free Ireland! Home rule for the Irish!
The spectators begin to leave. Annie moves towards the exit with the lawyer William Roberts and his family.
Roberts:

I didn't expect such a harsh sentence. None of those lads actually fired the shot that killed the police constable. I fear they are being made an example of....they are political prisoners not criminals. I can see you are upset, Annie. Go home now with my wife and daughters. I must go down to the cells and give what comfort I can to the young men. I did my best to help with their defense but I feel I have failed them. Go now.
EXT. The court steps

There is an angry crowd carrying banners. "Free the Irish patriots", "Home Rule for Ireland". As the Roberts's family near their carriage they are pushed and threatened by the crowd. The wife and daughters are visibly scared. But young Annie bravely steps forward and puts her hand on the chest of the aggressive man.
Annie:(loudly and firmly)
Stop. Don't you know recognise the family of Lawyer Roberts who defended the poor men in there. Let us pass!
Man and Crowd:
Oh forgive us, miss. Stand back, this is Lawyer Roberts family.
The name is echoed in the crowd and the mood changes. The protesters fall back allowing the family to leave.
INT. ANNIE'S BEDROOM IN INDIA
An old lady lies on a bed in India with a servant fanning her. We hear typical Indian sounds outside the open window.
VO:NaRRAtor (ANNIE)

It was the summer of 1863 when I spent in Manchester with friends of my mother, Mr and Mrs. Charles Roberts that opened my eyes to the injustice in the world. Those young men were hung in public, defiant to the end, believing in the rightness of their cause. Lawyer Roberts, as he was affectionately known among the working classes, gave his time freely to help and advise the accused who became known as the Manchester Martyrs,
EXT. INT William Roberts' OFFICES.
Annie is swept up in the bustle of the busy legal office. We become aware that old Mr Roberts is quite taken with young Annie. She follows him down the stairs from his offices.
ROBERTS:
Com on, Annie, follow me. We are going visiting. You've been a great help in the office these few weeks but it is time for you to see the real world.
iNT. Miners house.
We become aware of the contrast between THE two classes as we see the damp dingy interior of the miners house.
MINER:

I told them the brackets were faulty, Sir, but the foreman ignored me. Bloody bucket crashed down on me leg. Can't bloody work. No compensations, "No work, no pay", 'e says. I got a wife and three kiddies to feed. I just don't know what I can do...
He breaks down and cries. His wife and children look hopelessly on.
ROBERTS
Don't worry. I will take up your case with the colliery management...
mINER:
I'm grateful that you came but Oi can't afford your fees,Sir
ROBERTS
Shhh, don't fret. There are no fees. I am here to help. Now tell me all the details and I will see what I can do....now you were on the early shift....
EXTERIOR: Annie and Roberts leave the house. They pass scenes of deprivation in the adjacent houses. Half-starved children stare out with blank eyes.
Roberts:

The miners are treated like animals, Annie. If you go to the colliery, there are girls younger than you working underground, hauling carts of coal like a donkey, half-naked because of the heat. Many of the men get injured or are overcome by the gases. It is a short harsh life for most, you know, they die of coal dust on the lungs. Coughing and coughing.
They pass by gaunt mother holding a baby surrounded by 9 or ten children
ANNIE:
Mr Roberts, why do they have so many children if they have so little money?
Roberts:

Aye, they have one child almost every year after they are married. They do not know how to prevent it. A lack of education or the money to purchase preventative measures. The women are worn out by the time they get to forty.And the men are worn out by too much hard work. It's a harsh short life for these people, Annie. I do what I can to help, but I fear it is too little.
Annie and Roberts walk along streets which highlight the poverty and life in those times for the working classes.
Ext: Public scaffold

We see the three young men climbing the steps to the scaffold with the three nooses already waiting. (In the real life only one died immediately, the rest slowly strangled, one with the executioner hanging on his feet,to hasten the end, the other with a priest holding his hand. These images might be too grewsome).
narraTOR:

I realised what a sheltered and privileged life I had led. The dull eyes of those half-starved children living in such poor conditions haunted me on my return to my mother in London. It was my stay in Manchester that opened my eyes and I was consumed with a desire to help others. How different was the life of the poor working people from my own experiences. My Irish ancestors, the Woods...that was my family name... helped the royal cause hundreds of years earlier and laid the foundations of our fortunes.
Of course, my mother being Irish and my father half-Irish you can see why the fate of those young Irishmen moved me so much.
INT. AnniE's HOME year earlier. Early evening.

We see the contrast in conditions. This is a comfortable middle-class house. There are many religious symbols around. Her mother will have an educated Irish accent and her breeding should show. In this scene. Annie, is still a child of eight years old, She and and her elder brother, Harry are about to eat a meal. There is an empty place at the head of the table. The mother makes sure they pray before eating the meal.
Mother:

Annie, Harry, stop playing. We must say grace before the meal. Dear Lord, bless this table and the food thou has provided to us this day. We give thanks to your bounteous gifts. Take care of our dear Papa, now sitting with you in Heaven. Help us to grow more worthy of you each day and keep our hearts and minds pure. Amen. You may now begin. Henry! Don't be greedy. Your uncle may be the Lord Mayor of London but that does not entitle you to all the potatoes in England!
MOTHER:

Now I have something important to tell you. Thanks to your Uncle Reginald who has agreed to pay the school fees, you Harry will be starting at Harrow school. It is where most young gentlemen start their education. I will be moving near to the school and will take in other boys as borders to bring in some extra money. I am afraid your dear father, bless his soul, did not provide for us well after his death. You, Annie, being a girl cannot go to Harrow or any private college as your uncle does not think girls need an education. However, through a friend I have found a place in Dorset where you can be educated. It is run by a Miss Marryat, a good Christian woman. who has agreed to take you without any fees.
Annie: close to tears
No, Mummy, I don't want to leave you. Really. Please. Can't I stay with you and Harry?
MOTHER:

I am sorry, Annie. I have no choice. If you are to have an education, then this is the only way. Miss Marryat has only agreed because you will be company for her niece Amy who is about your age. You should be grateful. You will both be taught in her house in Dorset, right near the beach. It will be fun and you will have a friend to play with.
Narrator:

I was close to my mother and shed many tears when I said goodbye at the train station. The excitement on traveling on one of the early passenger trains was lost on me that day. My mother put me in the care of the guard and I was packed off with heavy heart. What I didn't know was I could not have gone to a better school in those days. Miss Marryat was a evangelical Christian but she was also a very progressive educator. It was the ideal place for the little curious and bright young girl...
INTERIOR GUARD'S VAN.
Annie is still eight years old. She is seated beside her suitcase and parcels and cages of chickens.
Guard:

Ok, Miss. I told your mother I would see you here safely. We are pulling in now to Axminster Station. Starting a new school eh? Lucky you. How did you like your ride in a train? You are a real pioneer, young lady. This railway line has only just opened up. A lot of folks are scared of traveling so fast. They think their souls will be left behind as the engine picks up speed (chuckles)....there.. can you feel us slowing down as the driver puts on the brakes. We are coming to the station. Woo, steady now. Wait and sit until we have stopped. The train wont go again until I wave this green flag.....let me lift you down to the platform. There we are. Ah, you see that man there. That's your name on his sign, ain't it. Bye, missy.
EXT. English RAILWAY station.
Annie emerges with her coachman who takes her luggage and lifts her onto the cart.We hear the guard's whistle and the sound of the steam engine starting off above the clip clop of the pony's hoofs.
Ext. English road, with couNtryside and the sea sometimes visible.
Annie sits on the cart clutching her a small suitcase, looking young and vulnerable.
Ext. Miss MarryAt's home school, Charnmouth, DORSET. (the house still exists)

The horse-drawn cart arrives at a large sunny house where she welcomed by Miss Marryat, a lady in her early to mid-forties with a kind face. We see she is lame. A girl, a year or two older stands behind her.
Miss Marryat:

Welcome Annie. This is my niece, Amy. She will keep you company. You will both learn together. Come along then, let me show you to your room. After prayers to thank the Lord for your safe arrival, we can have some supper together.
annie:
Thank you, Miss Marryat
Miss Marryat:
We are happy to have you. And please, dear, call me Auntie
INT. Annie's new bedroom.

In the bedroom, Annie unpacks her suit case. From it she takes a poster and carefully pins up a picture of Joan of Arc on the wall. And sets her Bible by the bed and a photo of her mother. We see she is a very disciplined child by the way she packs away her clothes.
INT. informal school room. It is a large, light room with a baby grand piano. A blackboard with an easel stands one side. There are many books on shelves.
miss Marryat:

At Fernhill, my pupils must learn to think for themselves. I do not want you to just memorise, or repeat after me like a silly duck. Quack,quack,quack. Hands up those who think girls are as smart or smarter than boys?
Annie and Amy shoot up their hands giggling.
miss Marryat:

You will learn to write properly, to appreciate the beauty of language and be transported by fine literature. You will conquer mathematics and science, lift your your soul with music while strengthening your body with physical exercise. Above all, (she becomes a little fanatical) you will learn to worship with humility, recognising only through Jesus Christ can you enter heaven. He is the one who gave his life to atone for your sins. On Sundays you will read no other book but the Bible......(smiles) but today being Tuesday, we start by reading from 'Fabulous Histories' or the 'History of the Robins' by Mrs Trimmer. From this you will learn to respect all God's creatures and treat them well. Annie, would you like to begin reading....
INT./EXT. Various scenes and SOUNDS AROUND SCHOOL

We see the two girls, sometimes with other children, reading, getting music lessons ( special teacher), learning Latin and German, playing sports like archery or going on long rambles in the countryside and enjoying picnics on the beach. We also see many scenes of Annie in praying in church.
INT: annIE;S Bedroom at Fernhill.
Annie is stripped to the waist and see her scouring her self, flagellation, with a homemade whip of twigs. You can see she is not too serious but she still winces with the pain.
Annie:
I pledge my life to the Lord Jesus.I pledge my life to the Lord Jesus. I pledge my life to the Lord Jesus
INT: Miss Marryat's dining room
The diners say prayers. Mildred the maid brings in the dishes. Amy and Miss Marryat tuck into their food but Annie does not eat.
miss Marryat:
What is wrong? Annie, why are you not eating? Are you ill?
annie:
I have decided to fast like St Catherine of Sienna. To deny myself food until His holy spirit enters me.
Miss Marryat:
Miss Marrayat wisely does not argue. and continues calmly.
Very well Annie. I can see you have made up your mind on this matter. Far it it from me to sway you from following a saint. Mildred, will you please clear Annie's plate.
The others resume eating and chatting while Annie sits isolated.
INT. Annie's bedroom evening time.
Annie is laying on the bed. There is a knock at the door. Miss Marryat enters. She is carrying a plate with a slice of apple pie on it.
Miss Marryat:

Annie, you missed dinner as well as lunch. St Catherine fasted because her mother was forcing her to marry a man she did not love. Jesus knows you love him and that you would make sacrifices for him. But he wants you strong to fight his good fight. God has produced this food from the fertile earth which he created. Do you want to throw his good works in his face? Let's ask him now Annie. Get on your knees and pray.... Oh Lord guide this servant into the right action so that she pleases you. Keep her on the path to good health so that her spirit remains strong forever to worship you. Amen.
They both get up.
miss marryat:
Do you think you might now like to have a piece of pie, Annie.
Annie:
Yes, Auntie, I think Jesus may want me to eat.
Miss Marryat leaves smiling to herself.
INT School Room
Amy and Annie with other boys and girls are learning music from a male tutor.
INT: Garden
Annie and Amy are learning archery
EXT BEACH
The two girls picnic on the sandy beach with Ms Marriot and the maid.
EXT. Woods
We see the girls on a nature trip. Ms Marryat is pointing out trees and plants. We get a glimpse of a fox or badger.
INT schoolroom:
We see the two girls writing and studying. We see them growing up in these scenes.
We are left with the impression of an idyllic and full life in the school.
Ms Marryat's Garden.
Annie now 14 years old is reading a newspaper.
Annie:
Auntie. Have you heard of Charles Darwin? He has just published a book called The Origin of the Species.
According to this newspaper report, Darwin says we developed from sea creatures, changing over millions of years.
Miss Marryat:

Yes, he apparently thinks we were once apes. Annie, the Bible tells us men were placed on Earth by God created in his own image. Would you believe this crackpot adventurer or the Word of the Lord written down by the prophets? Don't fill your head with that nonsense.
Annie continues to read, and become thoughtful.
INT: schoolroom
We see Annie grow into a young adolescent of 13 or 14.
miss Marryat:

Annie, this is a complex book. We need to dig deeper. What secret did Rochester have? Why did the author, Charlotte Bronte, bring in this element? What action did the revelation on Jane Eyre? Why was this essential for the narrative?
INT: SChoolroom
There are French phrases on the chalk board.
Annie:

Reading in French: Notre-Dame de paris,ou simplement Nortre-Dame pour Parisians,est la,cathedral de l'archidiocese n'est pas plusgrande cathedrales francaises , mai elle est indicutaablement, l'une des plus remarquables qu'ait produites l'architecture...
Miss Marryat:
Tres bien, Madamoselle Woods.
INt. School room. LATER DATE
Annie:
.....the mysterious horseman turned his black steed around and galloped off into the night. The end.
MISS Marryat:

Well done Annie, what an exciting tale. I think you might become a famous writer like my brother, Captain Marryat. He is well-known since he wrote "Midshipman Easy." Freddy, was quite a war hero and had many adventures at sea. I did so envy him. Looking after mother and my stupid leg kept me here. You will have no such things to stop you, my girls. Use your heads and you can conquer the world, God willing. Oh, Captain Marryat also wrote "Children of the Forest." You may may enjoy that. Borrow the copy I have on the shelf over there.
INT. Fernhill HoUse kitchen ( later date)

The two girls clatter into the room full of high spirits. We can see they have both grown into young women. Amy is more developed physically, while Annie remain quite slim but we can see the budding womanhood. A maid is preparing the breakfast and putting china on the table. Miss Marryat is sitting down at the table already.
Miss Marryat:

Girls, sit down. I have some sad news for you. I am going to Europe. My nephew has to go to Germany to see an eye specialist. He has cataracts and will go blind if he is not operated on. The best surgeon is located in Bonn. I will be accompanying him (pause).....and you two will come with me!
The girls squeal with excitement.
Annie
When Auntie, when?
MISs marryat:

We get a steamer from Southampton next week. I have had passports made and written to your mothers for permission. You can brush up on your languages while there. You already speak German and know a little French. It's time you saw a bit more of the world. We will try to visit Paris after Germany.
The girls are excited and start speaking in a mix of German and French. Breakfast is almost forgotten in the excitement.
miss marryat:

Come on girls, we must not keep the food waiting. First we must say grace. For what we are about to receive, may the Lord God make us truly thankful. May we begin and live this day and every day, worthy of You. Amen
The girls start to eat, but we can see they are still highly excited by their glances at each other. Miss Marryat notices but smiles indulgently.
EXt. German citIES and SIGHT

We see Annie and Amy enjoying being tourists in various locations. The cousin is pushed around in a wheel chair with his eyes bandaged. The young German University boys are attracted to the two English girls, especially to Amy who had grown into a rather voluptuous girl. Miss Marryat hurries the girls away from this unwanted attention.
miss marryAt:
Come on, girls, tomorrow we are going to stay at a chateau on the Rhine. I understand the Marquis of Douglas and Lord Charles, the sons of the Duke of Hamilton, are staying there for the summer.
EXT: CHATEAU
We see Annie and Amy at a large chateau. They are on the lawn with two boys. One boy is flirting with Amy but Annie is keeping her distance from the other boy.
AMY:
William, have you even kissed a girl, come on, tell the truth.
Charles:
Course I have.
AMY:
I don't believe you. I bet you have only kissed your sister. They look like virgin lips to me! What say you Annie? Does William have virgin lips? (Giggles)
Annie:(Pulls a face)
I don't know William usually has chocolate coated on them from all the bonbons he eats!
RODNEY:
I could show you how to kiss, Annie. The girl next door to us in Cambridge showed me last summer how to kiss properly. You start like this.
Rodney leans forward with lips pursed.
Annie:
Stop now Rodney, my lips are only used in prayer to the Lord Jesus. And to kiss the cross like this ( she lifts the cross around her neck). There are more important things than your silly kissing.
Annie goes back to reading her book while Amy teases and flirts with William.
EXTERIOR SCENES IN Paris. 1861/2
We see Annie, Amy and Ms Marryat visiting walking in Paris streets and entering the Louvre.Note the Eiffel Tower has not yet been erected.
INT: Louvre
Amy and Annie race ahead of Miss Marrayat
Amy:
Oh look Annie, you can see his little willy. See! See!
Annie refuses to look at the sculpture of the nude Spartacus and hurries on.
INT: Louvre
Annie stands rapt in front of painting "Christ appearing to the three Mary's".
Amy:Impatiently
Annie, do come along, Annie....
Ext. Cafe in paris.
Miss Marryat and a friend are drinking coffee. The two girls are close by.
FRIEND:

Have you heard the Bishop of Ohio is coming to Notre Dame next week. He is a good friend of my husband. The Bishop will be conducting a Confirmation in the cathedral. Would Annie like to participate, do you think?
Annie:
I heard, oh Auntie, may I? Please. I know all the catechism off by heart already.
Miss marryAt:
Why doesn't that surprise me. It's all a bit to flashy for my taste, too near the Catholics, but I have no doubts of your sincerity. If you really want to do this, Annie, it can be arranged.
INT. NotrE Dame CATHEDral.

We witness Annie and other girls overawed by the whole event. The richness of the vestments is in contrasts to the simplicity of the English churches. We see her face transfixed. Annie, dressed all in white, is on her knees at the altar. The Bishop marks her forehead with the cross.
BISHOP:
Be sealed with the gift of the Holy Spirit.
EXt. Battlefield
In her mind, we see a flash of her dressed as Joan of Arc on a horse.
Annie:
I fight for your Kingdom, Sweet Jesus. I am prepared sacrifice my life for you, my Lord
INT NoTRE DAME Cathedral
The ceremony rich in pageantry. Annie is obviously struck and impressed by this. She leaves full of the Holy Spirit.
EXT. by boat to England.
Annie and the others are on the boat crossing the English channel returning to England. We sense this is the closing of a chapter of her life.
NARRATOR:Over images of the boat

We returned to Fernhill for a few months. Europe had opened our eyes to a wider world and my French and German were now perfect. Miss Marryat refused to teach us anything more - insisting we learned to self-study. She was preparing us for the real world. I returned to my mother's house in Harrow but had no idea how soon I would have to face the reality of a world so different from the comfortable middle class bubble which up to now had protected me.
INT. Wood home
Annie is in the parlor of her mother's home. Her mother is sewing while Annie is reading.
mother:

Annie, you always have your nose in a book. Come with me today. I promised Aunt Mary that you would help out at St Barnaby's. The place has been left empty and she is helping clear it up so services can resume. You could help her for a few weeks until you decide what to do next.
iNT. Dusty church.
There are a number of women picking up items and hanging drapes. The sunlight catches the dust as a young man sweeps the floor. Mrs Wood and Annie enter.
Mother:

Hello Mary, this is my daughter Annie. She's recently returned from Europe and finished her schooling in Dorset. She has returned home to me. She can give a hand here in the Church she has nothing to do for the next few weeks.
mary:
Bless you child, we can do with all the help we can. 'Tis sad to see the house of God so neglected.
mother:
Annie needs to be kept busy. They say the devil makes work for idle hands. And who's the young man over there...
Mary:
Oh that is a young curate down from Oxford. Part of the seminary training. His name is Frank..er Besant. Handsome lad, eh?
It is obvious that Frank has noticed the sweet 16 year-old. As Annie wanders around, Frank approaches her. Frank is handsome in a rather ascetic way.
FRANK:
Hello, my name is Frank. I haven't seen you before. Do you live in the neighbourhood?
Annie:

I'm Annie. Yes, I have just returned home. I've finished schooling now. I went to Europe for a few months but now I am home again. My mother wants me to help out here... Aunt Mary said that you are a clergyman.
FRANK:
Not yet, I am finishing my studies and then I can be ordained.
Annie: (very ernest)
How wonderful to give your life to Christ. To serve our dear Lord, night and day must be so satisfying
FRANK: (A little taken aback)
Er, Yes....
Annie:
I believe Jesus has plans for me too....
Mother:Interrupting
Annie, come and help over here now
Annie breaks off the conversation. Frank obviously is not so fervent in his Christian belief but is nevertheless attracted to this serious young woman.
EXT. TRAIN STATION.

A party of elderly people are boarding the train for a trip to the seaside led by Aunt Mary. Annie and Frank are helping them board and find their seats. Annie and Frank sit next to each other. Both react when their knees accidentally touch. It is obvious neither of them have much experience of the opposite sex and are painfully aware of the other.
EXT. Different scenes at the seaside.
The Church group enjoy different activities and Frank and Annie are pushed together being younger than the others.
EXT train station
Annie is seeing Frank off. He is still rather stiff and awkward.
Frank:

I am sorry I have to leave early, Annie,but I have to get back to my studies in Oxford. I have enjoyed our week together. Em, I think it is important for a clergyman to have a wife to work with him in a parish, don't you think so?
Annie:
Yes, I suppose so.
frank:
Good. I would like us to get married, Annie
Annie is taken aback and does not answer, but Frank takes this this silence as assent, awkwardly kisses her on the cheek and strides off to catch his train.
INT/EXT; THE wood's home
Frank is seen knocking at the door.
ANNIE:
Don't tell him I'm here.
MOTHER:
You have to be honest with him Annie. He writes every week. And he is a handsome lad.
Annie hides upstairs and Mrs Wood answers the door.
Mother:
Why Frank, what a lovely surprise. I am afraid Annie isn't home but she will be sorry to have missed you. Come on in.
frank:

I hear you have establish many Buddhist schools in Ceylon.
Olcott:

Helena and I did a lot of research into the ancient texts. Sadly, Buddhism was declining. The locals were losing their culture and spiritual foundations. It was hard work at first but we have turned it around. There is much pride now. Educating the children so they understand their religion has been a large part of that. I am continuing to open new boys schools. We can visit one or two tomorrow when you have rested but first tell me about London. I haven't been back since the cremation...
Ext. Sri Lankan countryside, visiting schools.
Annie accompanies the old man. Olcott is garlanded by students and staff. We see scenes of the Countryside and life of the locals.
INT. Balcony at hill station bungalow
Olcott:

You know Annie , Helena and I were very close. Good chums, nothing more. We actually had nicknames for each other. I was Maloney and she was Mulligan. Do you know how we met? I had left the army, served the Government as a civilian adviser, but I was interested in the occult. It was the rage in America at that time. I went down to a farm in Vermont to investigate three children who attracted spirit visitors. Madam Blavatsky was there, also drawn by curiosity, I think. We hit it off. We made a odd pair. She was already overweight, untidy and laughed like a man. I was a reserved and disciplined army man. A rather sad widower, I guess. She had a great sense of humour and cheered me up. I followed her around while she was writing and holding seances. We eventually were drawn to India and felt this was a very spiritual land.
You know, Annie, she wrote to me about you. In her last few letters it was obvious she had grown fond of you but more than that... she wanted you to lead the Theosophical Society eventually.
Annie:
But I cannot channel Koot Hoomi and the other adepts. I think I do sometimes get messages but it may be just in my head... I cannot get the guidance she does.
Olcott:

Hush, let me be open with you. Helena did have clairvoyant powers but she wasn't above inventing things if she felt that was what was needed to get attention or create faith. She admitted it. I think she even showed you documents claiming she cheated and dared you to disbelieve. She didn't take herself as seriously as others.

Many things she had invented early in her life but wasn't allowed to let it drop. But she saw that it was not Koot Hoomi and the others which were needed to take the Theosophical Society to the next stage but YOU my dear, that down- to-earth, practical dynamo. The Masters will guide you. You are a great organiser which is why you became her right-hand man. Channeling and seances are no longer fashionable. Theosophy has to adapt now we are in the 20th century. We need to show the world how close each religion really is. Science is opening up much that was unknown but we are to explore the deeper mysteries of the soul.
Annie sits back and takes drink, looks over at the valley.
Olcott:

We will soon leave for India and Madras. Once you settle in the headquarters in Adgya, you will be able to plan how we can go forward. This country is remarkable for the different religions living side by side. There is a lot of poverty and disease but spirituality flows in the veins of every man women and child in this beautiful land.
Ext. Street scenes in INDIA
Crowds are waiting to greet Annie and Olcott. There are banners welcoming Annie Besant as they ride in an open car towards the Theosophical Society headquarter. Many rush to kiss her hand.
Annie:
How do they know my name?
OLcott:

The Indians are great readers. They have been reading your teachings and embraced them. They are also aware of your demands from the platform in England and in the British Times newspaper calling for Home Rule in India. You are a heroine!
annie:

Henry, I want to stay out of politics now I am here. The socialist and Marxists turned on me because of Theosophy. I tried for a few years to continue my social activism but I was forced out of all the organisations. Dear Charles still remained a friend but he no longer shared his strategies or, indeed, any intimacies. Now he has passed on. I can see your efforts have been towards education and I would like work with you on this. Did you know I sat on the London School Board for many years. Actually I only resigned when I knew I was coming to India.
INT hall in ENGLAND
Two members of the audience are talking while waiting for Annie to appear.
AUDIENCE 1
Well she can certainly still attract a crowd despite hiding away in India for more than a year. I heard she has been on speaking tours in the USA and Australia.
Audience 2:
I hear she has become a Hindu.
Audience 1:
A what...?
Audience 2:
Hindu. You know one of those religions for the natives out there in India.
Audience1:
Who is that sitting on stage. The man with the beard. Is that Colonel Olcott?
AuDience2

Oh no. Poor Olcott died with Mrs Besant at his side. That fellow is Charles Leadbeater. Apparently Mrs Besant thinks the world of him but most of the members think he is creepy. There are rumours that he is a little too friendly to the young boys he teaches.
Audience1
Well, I never, he looks so respectable sitting up there.
The organiser comes on stage.
organiser:

As those of you who are members are aware we lost one of our founders, and the President of the Theosophical Society, Henry Steel Olcott recently. He and Madam Blavatsky established our society headquarters in India. The Colonel is sorely missed but the Masters decided his help was needed on a higher plane.

It was the dying wish by our former president that he was succeeded by someone who has given so much to our Society. His wish, which been confirmed by votes from the London Committee and other branches around the world, that Annie Besant, should become the new President on this special day in 1907. May I present the new President of the Theosophical Society.
Annie walks on stage. She is dressed in Indian costume quite a contrast from her very fashionable English dress in earlier times.
Annie:

Brothers and Sisters, distinguished guests, ladies and gentlemen. I realise the heavy responsibility this honour of president has bestowed on my. Firstly, I am following two of the great figures of the 19th century, HPB, Madam Blavatski, and Colonel Olcott. They have pulled aside the veils of our higher purpose. They have been our guides in this world, a light for us to follow the path the hidden Masters have set for us. The Theosophical Society has enjoyed a popularity few expected. I believe the world is ready for us...
ANNIE' OFFICE in LONDON
Annie and several senior members of TS stand around
Committee member 1

This has become a scandal that threatens our very existence. Our German and American branches are threatening to break away. You have been warned about Charles Leadbeater before. This time is is more serious. The complaint is from one of our long term supporter and benefactor and it is his own children who have been encouraged in inappropriate behaviour by this man entrusted to teach them.
Annie:
These are just allegations. Charles Leadbeater has contributed so much to Theosophy. I refuse to believe he has done such a thing. He is outside now and we can ask him.
CommitteE member 2:
Annie, I know you are fond of the man, but we have no choice. He has to resign or we have to vote him out. It will come to a choice between TS and him.
ANNIE:
Very well, ask him to come in.
The door is opened at Leadbeater is asked to come in.
ANNIE:

Charles please come in. We have discussed the allegations. I am shocked and saddened to hear them. But I want to hear your side before we go further. Did you encourage these boys to .... er indulge in touching their.. er penises?
LEADBEATER:
You mean masturbate. Yes, I did.
The committee give shocked looks
LeaDBEATER:
These are healthy young boys at puberty. It is a natural at that age. I wanted them to overcome their guilt and worries that come from foolish tales of masturbation creating blindness.
ANNIE:

Charles, you may feel this is right but this will damage the Society if it gets out. I am sorry, but you either resign or we have to cancel your membership. It grieves me to give this ultimatum but we have no choice.
Leadbeater:

Very well, you know I hold you in the highest esteem and I would not like to hurt the Society in anyway. I did what I felt was right. Maybe I am too progressive for many. I will write a resignation letter tonight. Good day to you all.
The committee looks relieved but Annie does not look happy. She looks sad,
EXT. TS headquarters INdia
A bearded man is watching two young Indian boys splashing about in the water of the lake. We see it is Charles Leadbeater. After some time he goes over to talk to them.
INT TS headquarters
Leadbeater

Annie, do you remember HPB telling us to expect a world leader to appear. Well I think he is here. I have met him today in our grounds. I saw these two boys today and I think they were sent to us by the Masters.
Annie:
What boys, where?
LeadBEATER:
They were bathing in the lake. Their father works for us as a gardener.
ANNIE:

(Sighs) I hope this isn't going to be a repeat of the nonsense which went on in London. Much against protests of others I have let you back into the Society but there must be no repetition of ... well ... you know. Take me to meet them tomorrow. What are their names?
leadBEATER:
Jiddu Krishnamurti and his brother Nitya.
EXT. Grounds of TS
We see Annie and Leadbeater talking to the two boys. They look like typical local boys. Nitya is more animated while Krishnamurti is quieter. They walk together while Annie asks questions.
Annie and Leadbeater leave the boys and walk back to the house together.
Leadbeater:
Well, what do you think? Is one of them the new World leader for whom we are waiting.
Annie:
I don't know, Charles, I will make contact with the Masters this evening. I hope they will guide us.
The boys are running around, laughing, not knowing the change fate has in store for them.
Int TS ANNIE'S ROOMS
Annie is having breakfast. Leadbeater comes in.
LeADBEATER:
Good morning, Annie, do you have any news? Is one of these boys the one we have been waiting for?
Annie:

I had to wait a long time but the message came through. Yes the World Teacher we are expecting is close. The identity was not fully revealed so which boy, I cannot say. You realise our role is to groom him and develop his powers. That must be our prime purpose from now on.
LeadBEATER:
I will talk to their father. I have seen him around. I am sure he will be only too glad to have his sons educated at our expense.
Annie:
Please make sure proper papers are drawn up. We need to have control of their education, environment and spiritual development. The father must be made clear on this.
narrator:

I still remember my first sight of those two boys. Nitka seemed to be more intelligent and lively than his brother Jiddu, but Charles read their auras and was convinced the quiet boy was the one. However, we agreed to bring them both up together. It was fascinating to see how these raw young boys developed into sophisticated young men. Krishnamurti became like a son to me. I could not foresee that he would in the end cause my most serious heartbreak.
INT. sophisticated Party in UK house
Krishnamurti in his early twenties, dressed in western clothes, is mixing with the guests, quite at home.
party girl1
Oooh, Jiddi Krishnamurti, so are you going up to Oxford?
KRiShnamurti:
No, 'fraid not. Failed the entrance exam again. Mother Besant was quite upset with me. I really am not the academic type.
party girl1
Oh, Jiddu, what will become of you? I'm sure there are plenty of girls here who would love to marry you and keep you in nice suits like this one.
krisHnamurti:

I'm afraid they have big plans for me in India. I do not have much choice. Mother Besant says the hidden masters have already set out my path. Ugh. Never mind, lets not talk of this, now. Shall we dance?
INt. TS headquarters INdia
Annie is surrounded by Indian guests.
Annie:

My friends, as you know I have spent many years helping to found schools and colleges. Education is a key to a better life for these children. I have also spoken out on rights for Indian women - not always gaining me popularity from some men! I have adopted Hinduism as my religion, encourage an appreciation of the literature and arts of India. I have wanted to restore a pride in the greatness of India. Not forever thinking that foreign powers are superior.

When I came here in 1893, I said I would not get involved in politics. But it is becoming increasingly clear to me that unless political action is taken, India's silk and cotton trade will be lost to the colonial masters. I see British textiles in our markets, not India cloth. You Indians are barred from certain jobs and organisations by the British. Years, back back in London, I spoke of the need to give India home rule. I believe it is now time for Indians to push for this change. If you are to feel the pride in your nation then you must govern yourselves. Your fight is my fight. Let us make 1913, a year that marks the beginning of the struggle. Who can we get in to work with us. Can we come together on this, across politics, religions and castes?
INT. hall
Annie Besant is on stage giving a rousing speech.
annie:

....the colonial power is crushing the life out of the people. Their rule is one of broken promises. They are ignoring the needs of the people. If Britain still wants the benefits of India, his majesty needs to give more power in how this country is run. Your culture and religion is undermined by the British and your economy wrecked by their demands. India must become self-governing. A partner to the British crown , not a servant. Loyal subjects of King Edward but free citizens in their own country with Indians making decisions for Indians.
INT. TS OFFICE London
Group of Theosophists are discussing events in India
TS member 1:
I'm concerned about the news from India. I think our President is going too far. The society should not be getting mixed up in politics.
TS Member 2
I agree, what has Indian Home Rule got to do with our objectives, our philosophy? What do you think, Sir Alfred?
SIR Alfred:
Annie has always been a bit headstrong, jumps right in without thinking.
TS MEMBER 3:
To be fair, up to now she has kept quiet and focused on education. her peace. Maybe this latest enthusiasm will blow over.
inT. Foreign secretaries office
Minister and his private secretary are discussing situation
minister:
I'm not happy , Reginald, with this Besant woman stirring up unrest in India. Particularly when we could find ourselves in a war in Europe if this Hungarian clash with the Serbs doesn't quieten down.
REGInald:

Some of us can remember her from trade union days in London. She's a real firebrand. Mixed up with the Marxists then. I thought after she got caught up in this Eastern religion stuff, she would disappear into an ashram or something. Obviously not. Reports from our intelligence officers say she recently founded the All India Home Rule League and it's getting traction.
minister:

Get in touch with our chappie out there and warn him. If war breaks out and we are involved then she needs to be shut up promptly. We need India to be in a peaceful state. We might need to recruit some of natives for the army and we certainly are going to want trade to continue uninterrupted.
int. British colonial Office in Bombay
Annie is meeting with the Vice Roy
VICEROY:

Mrs Besant, I have given you the courtesy of arranging this meeting to tell you personally, his Majesties governments position. War has now been officially declared between Great Britain and its allies and the Austria-Hungarian Empire. You may not feel the effects here but our young men are dying on the battlefield. Your calls for a revolution here cannot, and will not be ignored.
ANNIE:

My dear young man, I fully support my home country in this unfortunate war but that will not stop me continuing my demand for Home Rule for the Indians. We must let the Indians have a say in government. I must and will continue to campaign or their behalf.
VICEROY:
Then you leave me with no choice. You will either be repatriated back to England or you will be interned here until the European conflict ends.
Annie:
I have no intention of returning to England,young man. Let me make that clear.

Very well. In view of your age and position, I will refrain from locking you up in jail. Please return home and we will make arrangements. I assure you it will be as comfortable as possible. Good day to you, Mam.
EXT OOTACAMUND
Annie ( now 70) draws up in a car with two British solders and a local government officer in attendance. The surroundings are beautiful, this is highland cool country.
local Government OFFICIAL:
Here we are Mrs Besant. I am sorry we have to do this.
ANNIE:
Hrmm!
local Government OFFIciAL:
You must remain here. There is a servant to take care of you and these two soldiers will not only make sure you stay put but will protect you.
ANNIE:

Young man, I need no protection from the Indians. And no matter how beautiful the surroundings, you have taken away my freedom. You have forcibly silenced my voice. Roses round the door do not compensate for this unfair internment!
EXT: Major city
Crowds throng the streets demanding the release of Annie Besant.
INT. Annie's Interment cottage, a month later
Annie answers a knock on the door. The local official is back
local Government OFFICIAL:
Mrs Besant, I have papers for your release. I am to escort you on the first part of your journey home.
Annie
Is the war over , after just a few month?
local Government OFFIciAL:
No Mam, the war continues. More and more men are dying. I cannot tell you why you have been released. Please pack. I will wait in the car.
Ext. Streets in Madras full of crowds. ANNIE is greeted like a film star.
int. huge hall
The hall is full of delegates to 1917 Indian National Congress. Chairman bangs gavel.
Chairman of meeting:
Please be quiet, quiet now. I now have the result of the election of President . I am pleased to announce that the President of our Indian National Congress is Mrs Annie Besant!

Cheers erupt. We are conscious of this tiny old lady making her way to the podium. She stands smiling amid deafening cheers. We see seated in the audience Gandhi. At this time he still wears western clothes. Later he approaches Annie.
Annie:

Why Mr Gandhi, I am pleased to see you here. I remember meeting you in London with Madam Blavatsky. You were still studying law as I recall. I congratulate you on your success on South Africa in forming the Natal Indian Congress and the work you have done for civil rights. When did you return? What are you plans now you are back in India ?
gandhi:

Yes, I returned in 1915 but decided to be quiet for a year or so until I understood what was going on. I have followed your various campaigns for a long time. In fact, I had a picture of you in my Capetown office when I was still doing legal work. Of course, I fully support Home Rule for India. But I am afraid I seek full independence from Britain. We cannot be part of the Empire or we will never be free.
Annie:
I'm afraid the British crown will not let India go without a fight. I want self-government but I do not want to see bloodshed or the people suffer more deprivation.
gandhi:

I believe we can have a campaign of non-violent resistance and achieve the goal. But the time for talking and negotiating is over. Your efforts are much appreciated but it is time we Indians took the lead.
Annie is dragged away by supporters, leaving Gandhi looking thoughtful.
EXT: Annie is seen with Gandhi but it becomes obvious she is second to him. He is now seen wearing the dhoti
narrator:

I did fully appreciate it at the time but that day was the last time I took centre stage. As a white woman, to be elected as President of the Indian National Congress, was quite a feat. But age was catching up with me. Mr Gandhi was drawing the crowds as the year ended and he became the leader of the Independence movement. We worked together at times but I feared his actions wold lead to violence... and they did.
INTERIoRS and Exterior of annie lecturing in various countries for the THeosophical society.

I continued to travel lecturing in the USA, Australia England and in my chosen home India. Charles Leadbeater continued to cause problems and we packed him off to Australia. Krishnamurti and I stayed together in California.
EXT: garden at TS Centre IN CALIFORNIA
Annie:
Where is Jiddu? I haven't seen him this morning
Emily lutyens:
He is in his room. He had another of his attacks. He is in great pain at these times
Annie:
I think it shows the Kundalini is awaking in him. The Divine Spirit is descending once more onto a Man. Jiddu...Krishnamurti will emerge as the World Teacher.
EMIly lutyens:

Sometimes, Annie, I think you expect too much of him. He is a simple young man who hates pomp and ceremony. He wrote to me that he was very uncomfortable during the trip to Australia where you took him to Charles Leadbeater. He and Wedgewood have ordained themselves as Bishops of the Liberal Catholic Church. He was very unhappy seeing all the gowns and colourful ceremonies. And you must be careful, yourself, the Theosophists are very much against this association of their President and this rebel Church. And I hear Leadbeater is also facing more accusations of behaving inappropriately with young boys. Annie, as your friend, I ask you not to push Jiddu. If you are right, he will come to it in his own time. We need to worry about these painful attacks, maybe he needs to see a doctor. His brother Nitya's lungs are getting worse, I fear. The dry air here is helping but I fear he will not be long on this plane.
Annie:

Charles is a good and dedicated man. His moves are guided by the Masters. I don't wish to hear any more nonsense about him. I know Jiddu is destined to lead mankind spiritually, I just get a little impatient with him. He seems so dreamy at times, Emily, you know I am a person of action. I set up the Order of the Star as his own movement. He talks so beautifully to the young men and women who all adore him, but he seems unwilling to assume the mantle of leadership. Anyway, help me up and let me go and see the poor boy. How is that husband of yours? I see the name Edwin Lutyens often cited as the finest architect alive today. The Indian nation will remember him with gratitude this current project in creating whole city..what's it called..er New Delhi.
INT: Emily's room at the TS California. She writes a letter to her husband, the architect Edwin Lutyens.
Emily lutyens:

My dear Teddy, I do hope you project for the Vice Royal's home and the plans for the new city in India are progressing well. I am sure you have designed a legacy for yourself and India. I am proud to have such a talented husband. Annie is proving stubborn as usual. She will hear no bad word about that dreadful man Leadbeater. He is facing criminal investigations now and I can tell you many of the senior Theosophists are angry and feel this will reflect badly on the Society. Annie is such a bad judge of men. Look at that seducer Aveling in London, who borrowed money from everyone. Bernard Shaw just played with her and then later attacked her. As you know I am very close to Jiddu Krishnamurti, almost the mother he never had, and he confides in me. He was disgusted with what he saw in Australia and I fear he is already slowly moving away from this role Annie sees for him. I am torn. It will break her heart but I also see a young man who has had his life mapped our by other and not allowed to develop normally. He does what he is told but I fear a break will come in not too many years. Currently he is worried about his brother who is dying of tuberculosis. This stress and his denial of the role of World Leader is behind his frequent painful attacks that force him to go to bed. I do my best, to keep them both happy but it wears me out sometimes. Do take care of your health on these frequent visits to India. I am afraid it is all too easy to catch disease there. I look forward to our reunion, all my love, Emily.
EXT: Order of the Star camp in Holland 1929. 3,000 Expectant young people are seated on the grass waiting for the World leader Krishnamurti to address them.
KRiShnamurti:

We are going to discuss this morning this morning the dissolution of the Order of the Star of the East. Many people will be delighted, others will be rather sad. It is a question neither for rejoicing nor for sadness, because it is inevitable ....
FULL SPEECH Show audience in tears and shocked.

Again you have the idea that only certain people hold the key to the Kingdom of Happiness. No one holds it. No one has the authority to hold that key. That key is your own self, and in the development and the purification and in the incorruptibility of that self alone is the Kingdom of Eternity.
MORE SPEECH....

So these are some of the reasons why, after careful consideration over two years, I have made this decision. It is not a momentary impulse. I have not been persuaded to it by anyone. I am not persuaded in such things. For two years I have been thinking about this, slowly, carefully, patiently, and I have now decided to disband the Order, as I happen to be its Head. You can form other organisations and expect someone else. With that I am not concerned, nor with creating new cages, new decoration for those cages. My only concern is to set men absolutely, unconditionally free.
Ext: Kalang Airport 1929( actually opens 7 years later)
Annie arrives to a welcoming crowd with Charles Leadbeater to visit the Singapore Lodge of the Theosophical society. Both are now very old.
EXT: STREET IN SINGAPORE
Annie and Leadbeater are in a taxi. They look out and see the bustling life in this city.
leadbeater:

Annie, can you feel the energy in this place. We have passed Temples, Churches and Mosques. All the races and religions are mixing here. Singapore points to the future. This place will grow into a place of importance,
Annie:
I just hope they do not neglect the spiritual side in their anxiety to make a fortune.
INT. Theosophical Society Singapore
Annie and Leadbeater meet the members and look at the photos on the wall.
Annie:

Look Charles at the photograph. It show dear Colonel Olcott with BP de Silva, the jeweler. he was the first president. Look at the date, 1889, it was the same year I met Helena Blavatsky in London. Oh my, it seems so long ago so much has happened. It has been an uphill struggle...
LEADBEATER:
We are not in good spirits,Annie,at this time. I think we are both shocked and saddened by the defection of Krishnamurti earlier in the year.
Annie:

How could we have gotten it so wrong, Charles. Have we been fooling ourselves with these messages from the Masters? Did we want so desperately to welcome a new Messiah, that we imagined it all? I am so tired. I do not feel I can fight any more.
leadbeater:

Annie, don't distress yourself. Jiddu still loves you like a mother. Despite his strict training under me, he is still fond of me. Look at all these people here. They believe in you and the Theosophical Society. You found the same on your visit to Australia and New Zealand. Look they are waiting for us. Time for us to take centre stage! Come, Annie.
The two old timers walk in front of the applauding audience.
INT. ANNIE'S HOME IN INDIA
Annie is in bed. There are many people outside the door waiting to say farewells.
narRATOR:

It was a blow to me when Krishnamurti renounced his role. Did I misread the Masters? Did Leadbeater do anything to him when younger? Jiddu denies this and still speaks fondly of him. Krishna still loves me, I can see, but he is determined to go his own way. I am disappointed, of course. but as I get older, I am more accepting. Did I make a mistake, thinking he was the chosen one, the new World Leader?.... But my own children, dear Mabel joined my Society and Digby has grown closer to me in recent years, This has been a great comfort. A fall down the stairs in my office ended my traveling days. And I find it harder to remember my speeches. Its funny how the early years remain fresh in the mind. I once wrote that on my tombstone I would like the words "She sought after the truth". Well, as a Hindu I wish to be cremated and there will be no grave. You know, in my reincarnation, I hope I can find more peace. This life was a struggle and I was always seeking more. Bernard Shaw always told me I took life too seriously. I think maybe he was right. I didn't find the Truth but I hope I have been useful...I feel I have led many lives while still in this one mortal body.
EXT: Funeral Pyre
We see the flames as Annie's body is burned. Huge crowds surrounded the body.
EXT: The quiet of the Ganges in the early morning. Her followers pour her ashes in the water.
CREDITS

GANDHI began to dress in simple white dhobi and started his campaign. As Annie Besant feared it did lead to bloodshed but eventually in 1947 India won complete independence. He remained respectful of Annie despite their differences.
KRISHNAMURTI eventually became a famous and highly- regarded spiritual leader, author and philosopher. He died in 1986.
CHARLES LEADBEATER died a year after Annie. He started the Anglo Catholic Church in Australia. Once again reports of sexual misconduct with young boys surfaced but he was never charged.

GEORGE BERNARD SHAW went from a penniless writer to a famous playwright creating plays such as St. Joan, and Pygmalion, which was turned into the hit musical My Fair Lady. He remained a socialist and wrote many books and pamphlets.

OSCAR WILDE. Wrote many plays such as The Importance of Being Ernest and Lady Windermere's Fan and the novel The Picture of Dorian Gray. Despite his fame and brilliance was thrown in jail for a homosexual relationship and emerged a broken and poor man dying in Paris soon after in 1900.
ROBERT STEAD became famous and is considered the father of the tabloid newspapers and investigative journalism. He drowned in the Titanic sinking after heroically helping others to safety.
Hypatia Bradlaugh and Mabel Besant both continued the work of their respective parents becoming activists for their causes.
THE THEOSOPHICAL SOCIETY remains an active world-wide organisation although in numbers has shrunk. The headquarters remain in Adyar, India.
Rev. Frank Besant remained in Sisley until his death in 1917, spending his leisure time collecting parish history. He is buried in St Margaret's Church graveyard.

ANNIE BESANT is still revered in India. There are several street named after her. She had written and spoken eloquently on independent governance for the India while still in London and was a major force in the movement in India years before Gandhi came on the scene. She founded many schools, supported women's rights and promoted both Hinduism and Buddhism, urging Indians to take a pride in their culture. In the West, however, she is largely forgotten. Other people have instead become associated with her pioneering efforts in women's rights, birth control, sex education. Her speeches and campaigns on Home Rule for Ireland and Trade Unions and her success in introducing free school meals and medical services for pupils are not remembered. Had Annie Besant gone into English politics, she would have probably been the first woman Cabinet Minister. She also found time to become a Freemason in Europe becoming the Grand Master in Co-masonry in England. A fine orator, an indomitable organiser and a truly remarkable woman.
